monogr.title: Archeion, or, A discourse vpon the high courts of iustice in England : Composed by William Lambard, of Lincolnes Inne, Gent
monogr.author: Lambarde, William

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
FOR had not this late aspersion trenched too much upon the pietie I owe to so worthie an Ancestor (as I dare say) the Kingdome would acknowledge; truly I should not have given my least assent to have advanced this to light,
(which too lately was, without my privitie, or liking.) But the crying Errors (arising from the untimely publication) call upon me, to vindicate him from that wrong (if any such can be) and my selfe from an imputed Apathie. But why doe I call them wrongs, and aspersions? since that sweet Odour hee hath left, cannot by their false ingredients be so sophisticated, but may by the judicious bee easily smelt out. And for those that delight meerely in superficials, neither weighing the sense, or defects, but swallow the Errours for Errataes; such as these it hath
alreadie passed. Others are to be expected, of meere active soules; and of these, some that will passe sentence (upon the Booke) before it come to judgement: I shall assigne them the Character, heeretofore occasioned upon this verie Worke;
Fooles will contend, without the cause discerning,
And argue most, of what they have no learning.

I have too much digressed: seeing my desires are to be repaired, for injuries past; not to labour to prevent I know
not what, to come: Grant me the first, and I shall appeale the other to thy judgement; and thinke, I have well tendred my dutie I owe to my Parents, and Countrey.
